title: Establishes a process for the regulation of collecting, recording, and disclosing confidential information by state employees
summary: Establishes a process for regulating the collecting, recording, and disclosing of confidential information by state employees; defines "confidential information".

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                 I N  A S S E M B L Y

                                   January 12, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced by M. of A. JEFFRIES -- read once and referred to the Commit-
         tee on Governmental Operations

       AN  ACT  to  amend  the  civil rights law, in relation to regulating the
         collection, recording and disclosing of  confidential  information  by
         state  employees obtained by state employees in the course of official
         duties

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  The  civil  rights law is amended by adding a new section
    2  50-f to read as follows:
    3    S 50-F. DISCLOSURE OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION BY STATE EMPLOYEES.  1.
    4  DEFINITIONS.  AS USED IN THIS SECTION, "CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION"  MEANS
    5  ANY  INFORMATION MAINTAINED OR OBTAINED BY A STATE AGENCY, STATE OFFICER
    6  OR STATE  EMPLOYEE  CONCERNING  AN  INDIVIDUAL'S  HEALTH  OR  DISABILITY
    7  STATUS,  INCOME  TAX  RECORDS, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, STATUS AS A VICTIM OF
    8  DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, STATUS AS A CRIME VICTIM OR WITNESS,  PUBLIC  ASSIST-
    9  ANCE  STATUS,  IMMIGRATION  STATUS  OR ANY INFORMATION THAT IS OTHERWISE
   10  PROTECTED FROM DISCLOSURE BY ANY PROVISION OF FEDERAL,  STATE  OR  LOCAL
   11  LAW.
   12    2. PROCEDURE FOR THE DISCLOSURE OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION.
   13    A. EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE PROVIDED IN PARAGRAPH B OF THIS SUBDIVISION, NO
   14  STATE  OFFICER OR STATE EMPLOYEE SHALL DISCLOSE CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION
   15  TO ANYONE EXCEPT ANOTHER STATE OFFICER OR STATE EMPLOYEE ACTING  IN  THE
   16  SCOPE OF HIS OR HER OFFICIAL DUTIES.
   17    B.  CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION  MAY  BE DISCLOSED BY A STATE OFFICER OR
   18  STATE EMPLOYEE ONLY IF:
   19    (I) THE STATE AGENCY EMPLOYING SUCH OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED BY
   20  LAW TO DISCLOSE SUCH CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION  AND  PROVIDED  THAT  SUCH
   21  DISCLOSURE IS LIMITED TO THAT REQUIRED BY LAW; OR
   22    (II)  THE  STATE  AGENCY  EMPLOYING  SUCH OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE HAS BEEN
   23  AUTHORIZED, IN WRITING SIGNED BY THE INDIVIDUAL OR, IF THE INDIVIDUAL IS

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD04800-01-1

       A. 1877                             2

    1  A MINOR OR OTHERWISE INCOMPETENT, SIGNED BY THE INDIVIDUAL'S  PARENT  OR
    2  LEGAL  GUARDIAN, TO DISCLOSE SUCH CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION, AND PROVIDED
    3  THAT THE DISCLOSURE IS LIMITED TO THAT  AUTHORIZED  IN  WRITING  BY  THE
    4  INDIVIDUAL; OR
    5    (III) THE DISCLOSURE OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION IS NECESSARY TO COOP-
    6  ERATE WITH A LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY OR AGENCIES INVESTIGATING THAT CRIM-
    7  INAL ACTIVITY.
    8    3.  PROCEDURE  FOR  COLLECTING AND RECORDING CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION.
    9  THIS SUBDIVISION SHALL APPLY TO ANY DOCUMENTATION, QUESTIONNAIRE, INTER-
   10  VIEW SHEET OR OTHER OFFICIAL FORM USED TO APPLY FOR OR OTHERWISE  ACCESS
   11  BENEFITS OR SERVICES PROVIDED BY THE STATE.
   12    A.  NO  STATE  OFFICER  OR STATE EMPLOYEE SHALL MAKE INQUIRY REGARDING
   13  COLLECTING OR RECORDING OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION OF  ANY  INDIVIDUAL,
   14  WHEN  SUCH  INDIVIDUAL, ON HIS OR HER BEHALF OR ON BEHALF OF ANOTHER, IS
   15  APPLYING FOR OR IS RECEIVING ANY SERVICE  OR  BENEFIT  PROVIDED  BY  THE
   16  STATE,  UNLESS SUCH CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION IS SPECIFICALLY REQUIRED BY
   17  FEDERAL OR STATE LAW TO BE PROVIDED AS A CONDITION OF  RECEIPT  OF  SUCH
   18  SERVICE OR BENEFIT.
   19    B.  IF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION IS REQUIRED BY FEDERAL OR STATE LAW TO
   20  BE PROVIDED AS A CONDITION OF RECEIPT OF A SERVICE OR  BENEFIT  PROVIDED
   21  BY  THE  STATE,  THE  STATE  OFFICER  OR  EMPLOYEE SHALL MAKE ONLY THOSE
   22  INQUIRIES NECESSARY TO DETERMINE IF AN APPLICANT OR RECIPIENT IS  QUALI-
   23  FIED  FOR AND OTHERWISE MEETS THE CONDITIONS FOR RECEIPT OF SUCH SERVICE
   24  OR BENEFIT.
   25    4. PENALTIES FOR UNAUTHORIZED DISCLOSURE. ANY STATE OFFICER OR EMPLOY-
   26  EE WHO VIOLATES THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION SHALL  BE  SUBJECT  TO  A
   27  FINE OF NOT LESS THAN ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS. ANY STATE OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE
   28  SHALL  BE  SUBJECT  TO A FINE OF NOT LESS THAN THREE HUNDRED DOLLARS FOR
   29  EACH VIOLATION OCCURRING WITHIN FIVE YEARS OF A PRIOR VIOLATION.
   30    5. OTHER LAWS RESPECTING  CONFIDENTIALITY.  NOTHING  IN  THIS  SECTION
   31  SHALL  BE  DEEMED  TO  LIMIT,  ABRIDGE  OR  OTHERWISE  AFFECT  ANY OTHER
   32  PROTECTION IN FEDERAL, STATE OR LOCAL LAW RESPECTING THE CONFIDENTIALITY
   33  OF INFORMATION.
   34    6. SEVERABILITY. IF ANY SUBDIVISION, SENTENCE, CLAUSE, PHRASE OR OTHER
   35  PORTION OF THIS SECTION IS, FOR ANY REASON, DECLARED UNCONSTITUTIONAL OR
   36  INVALID, IN WHOLE OR IN PART, BY ANY COURT  OF  COMPETENT  JURISDICTION,
   37  SUCH  PORTION SHALL BE DEEMED SEVERABLE, AND SUCH UNCONSTITUTIONALITY OR
   38  INVALIDITY SHALL NOT AFFECT THE VALIDITY OF THE  REMAINING  PORTIONS  OF
   39  THIS  SECTION, WHICH REMAINING PORTIONS SHALL CONTINUE IN FULL FORCE AND
   40  EFFECT.
   41    S 2.  Section 51 of the civil rights law, as amended by chapter 674 of
   42  the laws of 1995, is amended to read as follows:
   43    S 51. Action for injunction and for damages.    1.  Any  person  whose
   44  name, portrait, picture or voice is used within this state for advertis-
   45  ing  purposes  or  for the purposes of trade without the written consent
   46  first obtained as above provided may maintain an equitable action in the
   47  supreme court of this state against the person, firm or  corporation  so
   48  using  his name, portrait, picture or voice, to prevent and restrain the
   49  use thereof; and may also sue  and  recover  damages  for  any  injuries
   50  sustained by reason of such use and if the defendant shall have knowing-
   51  ly used such person's name, portrait, picture or voice in such manner as
   52  is  forbidden  or declared to be unlawful by section fifty of this arti-
   53  cle, the jury, in its discretion, may award exemplary damages. But noth-
   54  ing contained in this article shall be so construed as  to  prevent  any
   55  person,  firm  or corporation from selling or otherwise transferring any
   56  material containing such name, portrait, picture or  voice  in  whatever

       A. 1877                             3

    1  medium  to  any user of such name, portrait, picture or voice, or to any
    2  third party for sale or transfer directly or indirectly to such a  user,
    3  for use in a manner lawful under this article; nothing contained in this
    4  article  shall  be so construed as to prevent any person, firm or corpo-
    5  ration, practicing the profession of photography, from exhibiting in  or
    6  about  his or its establishment specimens of the work of such establish-
    7  ment, unless the same is continued by such person, firm  or  corporation
    8  after  written  notice  objecting  thereto  has been given by the person
    9  portrayed; and nothing contained in this article shall be  so  construed
   10  as  to  prevent  any  person,  firm  or corporation from using the name,
   11  portrait, picture or voice of any manufacturer or dealer  in  connection
   12  with the goods, wares and merchandise manufactured, produced or dealt in
   13  by  him  which  he  has  sold  or  disposed of with such name, portrait,
   14  picture or voice used in connection therewith; or from using  the  name,
   15  portrait,  picture  or  voice  of  any  author,  composer  or  artist in
   16  connection with his literary, musical or artistic productions  which  he
   17  has  sold or disposed of with such name, portrait, picture or voice used
   18  in connection therewith.   Nothing contained in this  section  shall  be
   19  construed  to  prohibit  the  copyright  owner of a sound recording from
   20  disposing of, dealing in, licensing or selling that sound  recording  to
   21  any  party,  if  the  right to dispose of, deal in, license or sell such
   22  sound recording has been conferred by contract or other written document
   23  by such living person or the holder of such right. Nothing contained  in
   24  the  foregoing  sentence  shall be deemed to abrogate or otherwise limit
   25  any rights or remedies otherwise conferred by federal law or state law.
   26    2. A.   ANY PERSON WHOSE CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION  WAS  DISCLOSED  IN
   27  VIOLATION  OF  SECTION FIFTY-F OF THIS ARTICLE MAY MAINTAIN AN EQUITABLE
   28  ACTION IN THE SUPREME COURT OF THIS STATE AGAINST THE PERSON OR PERSONS,
   29  FIRM OR CORPORATION DIRECTLY RESPONSIBLE FOR DISCLOSING  SUCH  CONFIDEN-
   30  TIAL INFORMATION, TO PREVENT AND RESTRAIN THE USE THEREOF.
   31    B.  IN ADDITION TO SUING FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF PURSUANT TO PARAGRAPH A
   32  OF THIS SUBDIVISION, AN AGGRIEVED PARTY MAY  INSTITUTE  A  CIVIL  ACTION
   33  AGAINST THE PERSON OR PERSONS, FIRM, OR CORPORATION DIRECTLY RESPONSIBLE
   34  FOR  DISCLOSING  THE  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION FOR THE GREATER OF HIS OR
   35  HER ACTUAL DAMAGES OR ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS. IN ADDITION TO ANY  MONETARY
   36  AWARD, AN AGGRIEVED INDIVIDUAL IS ENTITLED TO COSTS AND HIS OR HER ACTU-
   37  AL ATTORNEYS' FEES.
   38    S 3. This act shall take effect on the one hundred eightieth day after
   39  it shall have become a law.
